title: The Magic of Fontainebleau

curator Kimberly Jones and host Barbara Tempchin discuss the Forest of Fontainebleau and the important place it holds in the history of open-air painting. Produced in conjunction with the exhibition In the Forest of Fontainebleau: Painters and Photographers from Corot to Monet.

title: A Sculptor Looks at Rodin's Work

playurl: Painting
downloadurl: and Sculpture. In conjunction with the exhibition Rodin Rediscovered
keywords: on view at the National Gallery of Art from June 28
imageurl: to May 2
releasedate: Sidney Geist highlights some of the 366 catalogued works by Auguste Rodin that filled spaces on each of the East Building's four levels. With works from about 40 American and European collections
lastmodified": the exhibition recreated a typical Paris Salon of the 1870s. Twenty-nine sculptures filled the Upper Level Galleries
column16: continued downward through the building with nine sections devoted to different themes of Rodin's work
column17: and ended on the Concourse with a new eight-ton bronze cast of The Gates of Hell with its 186 figures. In this lecture recorded on September 27
column19: Geist brings his unique perspective as a sculptor to the examination of Rodin's work
column20: expressing how difficult it is to separate Rodin's technical ability from the mystical quality of his sculpture. This intertwining of the human and the divine
column21: the mundane and the transcendent led Geist to remark of Rodin and his apprentice
column22: Constantin Brancusi: """"Sculpture is the place we read their spirits.""""""

title: Concerning America

column16: spanned Stieglitz's career. It demonstrated how a photographer can alter the aesthetics of his art and meaning through cropping
column20: and printing process- and also the extraordinary commitment a photographer has to his work. One of the most important photographers of his generation
column21: Gowin (born 1941) is the son of a Methodist minister and considered America and Alfred Stieglitz (1934) to be his second bible. For this lecture recorded on November 29
column23: Gowin used the title of his undergraduate senior thesis
column24: demonstrating his strong connection with Stieglitz and Robert Frank's The Americans (1958). Tracing the influence of Stieglitz throughout his career

title: Art and Espionage: Michael Straight's Giorgione

imageurl: David Brown sheds light on Straight's vocation as a collector by attempting to connect his activities as a Soviet sympathizer and agent with his interest in the Giorgione painting and the technical evidence gathered about it. ""

title: Picasso and the Concept of the Masterpiece
thumbnailurl: and art critic
playurl: The Nation. In this lecture recorded on September 19
keywords: at the National Gallery of Art
tags: Arthur C. Danto assesses early works in Pablo Picasso's (1881-973) career as a starting point for considering the concept of the masterpiece. The understandable but obsessive tendency of Picasso scholarship has been to treat even his simplest works as evidence that his cognitive powers had almost mythic dimensions. Danto argues that much of Picasso's early work became part of history only retrospectively because he became a great artist- mythic a priori. An artist makes certain choices in materials when he believes himself to be embarking on a masterpiece. By investing in a large-scale canvas
imageurl: its lining
presentationdate: and other expensive materials for a painting
releasedate: an artist demonstrates the meaning this particular work intended to have relative to his other works so far. It is a conservation gesture-not part of the internal or aesthetic meaning of the work
lastmodified": but a declaration of achievement and hope. Citing Picasso's rose period work Family of Saltimbanques (1905)
column17: and the African-influenced period work Les Demoiselles d'Avignon (1907)
column18: Danto considers the meaning of a masterpiece in an artist's life in terms of the language of beginnings and endings. One works up to a masterpiece
column19: which defines a period of endeavor
column20:
and after that the artist may change direction entirely.

"

title: Lodovico Carracci: Observations on a Faulted Genius
duration: Arthur Kingsley Porter Professor of Fine Arts
thumbnailurl: Fogg Art Museum
playurl: Harvard University. At the time of the exhibition Prints and Related Drawings by the Carracci Family
downloadurl: on view from March 18 to May 20
tags: at the National Gallery of Art
imageurl: Sydney J. Freedberg presented his observations on Lodovico Carracci (1555-1619)
presentationdate: the oldest of the family of Bolognese artists that included cousins Agostino (1557-1602) and Annibale (1560-1609). Together the Carracci profoundly altered the course of Italian art in the later years of the 16th century and laid the basis for the baroque style that would dominate the century to come. In this lecture recorded on April 8
lastmodified": Freedberg opposes the perception of Lodovico as a flawed artist outdistanced by his younger cousins. Providing a more comprehensive account
column16: Freedberg argues that the artist's expressive capacity- seen in his sensuous handling of paint
column18:
and innovative chiaroscuro- was both his strength and defect.

"

title: Artists in Residence: Henry O. Tanner in the Holy Land

thumbnailurl: Gwendolyn H. Everett focused on Henry Ossawa Tanner’s (1859-1937) visits to the Holy Land

keywords: Everett explains the formative influence of Tanner’s upbringing in an educated
tags: religious family in post-Civil War Philadelphia. Tanner’s father was a minister and
imageurl: later
presentationdate: a bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church
releasedate: and his mother administered a Methodist school. Tanner enrolled in the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts as the only African American student in 1879
column17: encouraged a progressive method of study from live models instead of plaster casts
column18: which profoundly affected Tanner. after 1891 Tanner resided primarily in France; by 1895 his paintings were mostly of biblical themes
column19: and in 1897 he made his first trip to the Holy Land
column20: where his firsthand experience led to mastery of religious subject matter. He visited the region several times to explore mosques and biblical sites
column21: and to complete character studies of the local population
column22: as he had learned from Eakins. Tanner invigorated religious painting with modernism and with his deeply rooted faith

achieving renown in the international art world.

title: Oil and Water: De Kooning in His Studio

imageurl: Shiff explores de Kooning’s involvement with change: he thought of himself as always evolving
presentationdate: and his work could not be classified under a single style. Second
releasedate: Shiff describes the physicality of de Kooning’s work: the artist became involved with materials of real substance and engaged his body with these materials by pushing
column17: Shiff shares how to look at and think about de Kooning’s figures and representations
column18: which initially might not be recognizable.  Fourth
column19: de Kooning resisted any description of himself more elaborate than painter: here Shiff addresses de Kooning’s objections to abstract art—even though he made abstract work

he did not consider himself an abstractionist.

title: William H. Johnson

lastmodified": he was accepted into the prestigious National Academy of Design. Noted watercolorist Charles Webster Hawthorne provided critical mentorship at the academy

column17: and sponsored his further training in Europe. Johnson supplemented this sponsorship with prizes awarded by the academy and funds earned working for Ashcan School painter George Luks. In 1920s Paris
column18: Johnson lived in the former studio of James McNeill Whistler and became acquainted with Henry O. Tanner
column19: an African American expatriate artist who had achieved international acclaim and who would become a pivotal figure in Johnson's rise to prominence. Follow along as Everett illustrates Johnson's journey—marked by determination

and bolstered by the support of influential artists—that led him to become one of the greatest American artists of the 20th century.

title: Michelangelo's David-Apollo: An Offer He Couldn't Refuse

thumbnailurl: Baccio Valori. The double name of this unfinished work

title: Historical Perspectives: African American Art
thumbnailurl: and professor of art
playurl: University of Maryland
downloadurl: College Park. On January 11
tags: the National Gallery of Art announced an initiative to address the underrepresentation of minorities—particularly African Americans
imageurl: Hispanic Americans
presentationdate: and Native Americans—in the museum profession. In response
releasedate: David Driskell presented a lecture at the Gallery on February 11
column16: on multi-cultural representation in art museum collections and exhibitions and among staff and visitors. Unresolved issues in our cultural history raise questions about why the arts have been divided along racial lines—if
column18: all art emanates from the salient desire to express the inner urges of the human spirit. This quality we all possess is colorless
column20:
and uncluttered by feelings of racial superiority. The insistence on dividing art in the United States along racial lines demonstrates a response different in both thought and action than that seen in older cultures and ancient societies. Driskell hopes that these impending initiatives allow us to enter the 21st century with a more holistic view of our history and the cultural pluralism that is the privilege of this nation.

title: A Conversation with Calvin Tomkins: """"Duchamp: A Biography""""""
duration: curator of modern prints and drawings
thumbnailurl: and Calvin Tomkins

tags: Calvin Tomkins shares the history of his relationship with Marcel Duchamp and the process of writing a biography on this enigmatic artist. As a foreign news writer for Newsweek with hardly any knowledge of Duchamp or modern art
imageurl: Tomkins was assigned to interview him in 1959. The interview was so fascinating that it led to Tomkins’ first interest in modern art. After joining The New Yorker as a staff writer in 1960
presentationdate: one of Tomkins’ early profiles was on Duchamp; two years later he was asked by the Time Life series to write its book on the artist. Eventually
releasedate: Tomkins approached Duchamp’s widow about the idea of writing a proper biography on the artist. Alexina "Teeny" Duchamp asked why he would want to do that
lastmodified": but granted permission as long as he did not write anything too personal. Tomkins relied on hours of recorded conversations between himself and Duchamp
column16: as well as interviews with his contemporaries and letters from Duchamp saved by others. Duchamp saved nothing
column17: traveling light all his life. In this biography
column18: Tomkins demonstrates that Duchamp was agnostic about art
column19:
believing that life was more important.

"

title: Elson Lecture 2013: A Conversation with Glenn Ligon

column17: 300 striking African American sanitation workers in Memphis in 1968 and made famous in Ernest Withers' photographs of the march. Proclaiming "I Am a Man
column18: " the signs evoke Ralph Ellison's famous line—"I am an invisible man." Approximating the size of these signs
column19: Ligon’s roughly made painting combines layers of history
column21: and physical material in a dense
column22: resonant object. As the first painting in which the artist appropriated text
column23: itis a breakthrough. In subsequent works he would transform texts into fields of semilegible and masked meanings. The Gallery owns sixteen works by Ligon

including a suite of etchings and a print portfolio.

language: Emory University. Costanza Piccolomini was Gianlorenzo Bernini’s beloved. His passion for this woman was so strong it inspired the sculptor to preserve her beauty in one of his most captivating portrait busts and to commission a violent crime against her. But until now
thumbnailurl: little has been known about the woman herself. In this lecture recorded at the National Gallery of Art on March 10

tags:
to discuss the nature of Bernini’s artistry and the surprising life of this remarkable woman who forged a career as an art collector and dealer in the wake of their tempestuous affair.

releasedate: the exhibition brings together some 70 works in a variety of media to examine the fascinating artistic dialogue that developed between the two. Degas/Cassatt is on view through October 5

playurl: this experience inspired his first connected series of works. It became still more important to him in the traumatic aftermath of his father’s death. During the course of his life he viewed the film some two hundred times
downloadurl: and many of his most famous paintings

title: Ursula von Rydingsvard
thumbnailurl: was born in 1942 in Deensen
playurl: a small German town where her Polish-speaking Ukrainian father was conscripted by the Nazis to work the land during World War II. The family remained there until the end of the war
downloadurl: and then moved through nine camps for displaced persons in five years. After immigrating to the United States at age eight
keywords: von Rydingsvard and her family carved out a new life for themselves. She earned an MFA from Columbia University in 1975
tags: and emerged from her studies focused on the cedar 4 Ã 4 beams that would define her sculptural practice. Although her work is abstract
imageurl: the artist has acknowledged a strong correlation to the human figure. This link is most visible in her vertically oriented conical works
presentationdate: exemplified by Five Cones (1990–1992)
releasedate: which was donated to the National Gallery of Art by Sherry and Joel Mallin in 2011. The gridlike format and the organic flow of von Rydingsvard’s materials give Five Cones its structural and visual tensions. It is this compromise formation—the artist’s physical aggression toward her material together with the considerable refinement of form—that gives strength to von Rydingsvard’s work. In honor of the installation of Five Cones in the East Building Atrium
lastmodified": von Rydingsvard discussed the sculpture within the context of her career in this lecture recorded on September 21

duration: Part 1: “A Glorious Galaxy of Monuments”: Photography and the Archaeological Survey of India after Tripe""
thumbnailurl: curator of photographs
playurl: India Office Collection
downloadurl: The British Library. British army officer Captain Linnaeus Tripe (1822–1902) occupies a special place in the history of 19th-century photography for the outstanding body of work he produced in India and Burma (now the republic of Myanmar) in the 1850s. With few models to follow
keywords: he used photography to explore these little-known cultures
tags: working under the auspices of the British East India Company. On December 10
presentationdate: the National Gallery of Art hosted a public symposium to accompany the exhibition <i>Captain Linnaeus Tripe: Photographer of India and Burma
releasedate: 1852–1860. On view September 21
column17: the exhibition traces Tripe’s work from his earliest photographs made in England (1852–1854)
column18: to ones created on expeditions to the south Indian kingdom of Mysore (1854)
column20: and again to south India (1857–1858). Many of his photographs were the first to document celebrated archaeological sites and monuments
column21: ancient and contemporary religious and secular buildings — some now destroyed — as well as geological formations and landscape vistas. Yet the dynamic vision Tripe brought to these large
column22:
technically complex photographs and the lavish attention he paid to their execution indicate that his aims were artistic as well.

"

downloadurl: 2015. After Giorgio Vasari described Piero in 1550 as an oddball misanthrope—“more like a beast than a man”—the painter was generally relegated to the margins of art history. American collectors

imageurl: held on March 19
releasedate: Virginia Brilliant explores how changing tastes and opportunities prompted American collectors to acquire major works by this eccentric artist. Piero di Cosimo: The Poetry of Painting in Renaissance Florence is on view through May 3

title: Art Is For the Spirit: Recent Prints and Sculpture at Gemini G.E.L.

playurl: Gemini G.E.L. is an artists' workshop and publisher of limited edition prints and sculptures. Known for a willingness to embrace new technology and tackle complex projects

which allows the white neon light to reflect off the wall. This arrangement of skewed perspectives evokes the political turmoil caused by the election of America’s first black president and the country’s contemporaneous involvement in two wars.

"

title: PALM
language: This is one of six silkscreened paintings that show enlarged handprints taken from declassified United States government documents obtained through the Freedom of Information Act. The handprints belong to soldiers accused of detainee abuse in Iraq
thumbnailurl:
and the titles of these pieces are also taken from those documents.

"

title: Target
duration: Johns was known early in his career for returning recognizable objects
thumbnailurl: to the visual arts following the intensely personal
playurl: gestural painting of the abstract expressionists. He presented these familiar items in a cool
downloadurl: seemingly detached
keywords:
and often enigmatic manner. The tactile quality of his surfaces in works like this one stand out and are a testament to the close relationship Johns perceived between painting and sculpture.

"

title: Mountains and Sea
duration: This work is a perfect example of Frankenthaler’s technique of making pictures entirely by "staining
language: " a process in which she poured thinned paint onto raw
thumbnailurl: unprimed canvas. This method results in fields of transparent color that seem to float in space
playurl: with the weave of the canvas establishing the flatness of the image. Her arrangement of colors and shapes often evoke the natural environment
downloadurl:
and each work creates a unique visual space and atmosphere.

"

title: Hope is: Wanting to Pull Clouds
language: Hope is: Wanting to Pull Clouds
playurl: polyester resin and acrylic on canvas
downloadurl: National Gallery of Art
keywords: Washington
tags: Gift of the Collectors Committee. The boy in this work was probably inspired by a 15th- or 16th-century German print; he is shown pulling ropes
imageurl: perhaps symbolizing his effort to reach for the clouds. To create the background
presentationdate: Polke stitched together fragments of fabric and dipped the resulting surface in polyester resin. He then poured paint on the back of the work and shifted the canvas to create different shapes. Finally
releasedate: he painted the figure itself. All told
lastmodified":
this work took Polke a year to complete.

"

title: Great America
duration: This painting reimagines a boat ride into a haunted tunnel at an amusement park as the Middle Passage—the forced journey of slaves from Africa to the Americas. What might in other hands be a work of heavy irony becomes instead a delicate interweaving of the histories of painting and race. The canvas
language: which is stretched directly onto the wall
thumbnailurl:
creates a screen or backdrop onto which viewers project their own associations triggered by the powerful imagery.

"

title: Conversation with Collectors: Virginia Dwan and James Meyer
thumbnailurl: deputy director and chief curator
playurl: Dia Art Foundation. The remarkable career of gallerist and patron Virginia Dwan is featured front and center for the first time in an exhibition of some 100 works
downloadurl: including highlights from Dwan's promised gift of her extraordinary personal collection to the National Gallery of Art. Founded by Dwan in a storefront in Los Angeles in 1959
keywords: Dwan's West Coast enterprise was a leading avant-garde space in the early 1960s
tags: presenting works by abstract expressionists
imageurl: neo-dadaists
presentationdate: pop artists
releasedate: and nouveaux rÃ©alistes. In 1965
lastmodified": Dwan established a gallery in New York where she presented groundbreaking exhibitions of such new tendencies as minimalism
column17: and land. The exhibition traces Dwan's activities and the emergence of an avant-garde gallery in an age of mobility
column18: when air travel and the interstate highway system linked the two coasts and transformed the making of art and the sites of its exhibition. On September 27
column20: at the National Gallery of Art
column21: Virginia Dwan and James Meyer join in conversation to celebrate the opening week of the exhibition Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery

title: The Reception of Paolo Veronese in Britain (c. 1600–1900)
language: University of St. Andrews. In this lecture recorded on October 12
playurl: at the National Gallery of Art
downloadurl: Peter Humfrey surveys the reception of Venetian artist Paolo Veronese in Britain from the early years of the 17th century
keywords: when his paintings first began to arrive there
tags: until the end of the 19th century
imageurl: when some of the finest examples in British private collections began to be exported to the United States. Humfrey focuses on the changing attitudes toward the artist over three centuries
presentationdate: particularly as reflected in the history of collecting. He also considers the pronouncements of critics such as Sir Joshua Reynolds and John Ruskin
releasedate:
and the possible influence of Veronese on English painters.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
language: Holcombe T. Green Curator of American Paintings and Sculpture
thumbnailurl: Yale University Art Gallery. The genre of still life has enjoyed unexpected power in America’s artistic tradition. Its periodic resurgence provides distinct perspective on the nation’s cultural development hewn to individual experience. Speaking at the inaugural John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
playurl: held on October 22
keywords: at the National Gallery of Art
tags: Mark D. Mitchell offers a new look at still life
imageurl: its meaning in America
presentationdate:
and its potential for future study. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a generous grant from The Walton Family Foundation.
"

title: Discoveries from the Dwan Gallery and Virginia Dwan Archives
thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art. In this lecture held on September 26
downloadurl: as part of the Works in Progress series at the National Gallery of Art
keywords: Paige Rozanski sheds light on the discoveries she made during her research at the Dwan Gallery Archives and the Virginia Dwan Archives in preparation for the exhibition <i>Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
tags: 1959–1971. Rozanski underscores the integral role this material played in planning the exhibition
imageurl: illustrates how the archives contributed to scholarship
presentationdate:
and outlines her approach to writing the chronology and exhibition history published in the exhibition catalog.

"

title: Diamonstein-Spielvogel Lecture Series: Thomas Struth
thumbnailurl: consulting curator
playurl: department of photographs
downloadurl: National Gallery of Art
keywords: and Andrea Nelson
tags: associate curator
imageurl: department of photographs
presentationdate: National Gallery of Art. Thomas Struth was born in Geldern
releasedate: Germany
lastmodified": in 1954. He first studied painting with Gerhard Richter at the Kunstakademie DÃ¼sseldorf before turning to photography in 1976 and becoming one of Bernd and Hilla Becher’s earliest students. In the late 1970s he began to make a series of black-and-white photographs of empty urban environments that established his international reputation. In the late 1980s he conceived another series
column17: where he photographed in some of the world’s most celebrated museums. These large color pictures
column19: explore the different functions that art fulfills in our modern
column20: secularized world and the ways in which people experience paintings today
column21: including the notion of the museum as a sacred pilgrimage site. As his interest in the idea of worship and pilgrimage expanded
column22: Struth launched a series titled Places of Worship in 1995. In his Family Portraits series
column23: which includes photographs of Struth’s friends as well as of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh
column24: all the works are infused with a sense of the forces that inform his subjects’ lives. As he has done throughout his career
column25: Struth exploits the gap between what was planned and what actually transpired—something that is fundamental to the art of photography. Struth has eight prints on view in the exhibition Photography Reinvented: The Collection of Robert E. Meyerhoff and Rheda Becker at the National Gallery of Art through March 5
column31: in conjunction with the exhibition and as part of the Diamonstein-Spielvogel Lecture Series
column32:
Thomas Struth discusses his career and traveling exhibition Nature & Politics.

"

title: Introduction to the Exhibition In the Tower: Barbara Kruger
thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art. A focus installation on the work of American artist Barbara Kruger (b. 1945) will reopen the East Building Tower Gallery after the space's nearly three years of renovation. Inspired by the Gallery's recent acquisition of Kruger's <i>Untitled (Know nothing
playurl: Believe anything
downloadurl: Forget everything) (1987/2014)
keywords: the exhibition comprises related images of figures in profile over which Kruger has superimposed her striking figures of speech. The distinctive direct address of Kruger's texts (using active verbs and personal pronouns) contrasts with her selected images of passive figures to create arresting conceptual works of great visual power. In this lecture held on October 23
imageurl: at the National Gallery of Art
presentationdate: Molly Donovan introduces the exhibition In the Tower: Barbara Kruger
releasedate: on view through January 22

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
description: II: Which is Which? The Serious Fun of Trompe l'Oeil""
thumbnailurl: department of art history
playurl: University of Delaware. Trompe l’oeil art challenges viewers to make perceptual distinctions between things that look extraordinarily similar. It stages lessons in perception
downloadurl: imitation
keywords: and deception while piquing our delight in the pleasures of wit. Drawing upon the National Gallery of Art’s important collection of American still life painting
tags: Wendy Bellion explores the serious fun of illusion in a lecture from the inaugural John Wilmerding Sympsoium on American Art
imageurl: held at the National Gallery of Art on October 22
presentationdate:
2016. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a generous grant from The Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: A Revolution in Color: The World of John Singleton Copley
duration: professor of history and Carl and Lily Pforzheimer Foundation Director of the Schlesinger Library
thumbnailurl: Harvard University. Looking through the eyes of John Singleton Copley
playurl: Jane Kamensky reveals an unknown American Revolution. In this lecture held on October 30
keywords: at the National Gallery of Art
tags: Kamensky draws from her new book on Copley and his world to untangle the web of principles and interests that shaped the age of America’s founding. Copley’s prodigious talent earned him the patronage of Boston’s patriot leaders
imageurl: including Samuel Adams and Paul Revere. But the artist did not share their politics
presentationdate: and painting portraits failed to satisfy his lofty artistic goals. When resistance escalated into all-out war
releasedate:
Copley was in London. The magisterial canvases he created there—several of which are now in the National Gallery of Art collection—made him one of the towering figures of the British art scene: a painter of America’s Revolution as Britain’s American War. This program is coordinated with and supported by the Smithsonian National Portrait Gallery.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
description: III: Seeing in Detail: Frederic Church and the Language of Landscape""
thumbnailurl: department of the history of art
playurl: Yale University. What does it mean to see a work of art “in detail”? Speaking at the inaugural John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
downloadurl: held on October 22
tags: at the National Gallery of Art
imageurl: Jennifer Raab considers broader questions of detail
presentationdate: vision
releasedate:
and knowledge in 19th-century America by looking at a few of Frederic Church’s most famous landscape paintings. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a generous grant from The Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
thumbnailurl: Rachael Z. DeLue
playurl: associate professor
downloadurl: department of art and archaeology
keywords: Princeton University. The modern American artist Arthur Dove (1880–1946) drew inspiration from the natural world when making his paintings and assemblages
tags: but he also played around with found objects
imageurl: popular music
presentationdate: sound technology
releasedate: aviation
column19: including his own signature. The circle motifs that appear persistently across Dove’s art serve to signify and connect these disparate things
column20: creating a vital and unique form of abstraction
column21: one resolutely if paradoxically bound to objective reality and material existence. As Dove himself said
column22: “there is no such thing as abstraction
column23: ” preferring the term “extraction” to describe the essential relationship between his work and the world. Speaking at the inaugural John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
column26: at the National Gallery of Art
column27: Rachael Z. DeLue discusses some of the chief characteristics of Dove’s extractions
column28:
focusing on examples from the Gallery’s collection. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a generous grant from The Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
thumbnailurl: Pamela M. Lee
playurl: Osgood Hooker Professorship in Fine Arts
downloadurl: Stanford University. In 1969 Nancy Holt and Robert Smithson collaborated on their first video together
keywords: <i>East Coast
tags: West Coast. Clocking in at twenty-two minutes
imageurl: the video featured the two artists playing the roles of East Coast intellectual and West Coast hippy respectively
presentationdate: trading perspectives on art and life as a series of bicoastal clichÃ©s. Virginia Dwan
releasedate: Smithson’s most important patron
lastmodified": occupied a singular position relative to the art scenes of Los Angeles and New York. For the public symposium keynote address given on November 18
column17: in conjunction with the exhibition <i>Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
column19:
Pamela M. Lee revisits the history of the Dwan Gallery as a negotiator of two distinct but converging art cultures and the formative role Virginia Dwan played in bringing them closer together.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
thumbnailurl: department of modern and contemporary art
playurl: Metropolitan Museum of Art. American painter Marsden Hartley (1877-1943) entered the modernist canon as a result of the abstract paintings he created in Germany in 1914-1915. But the paintings he created of his home state of Maine late in his career beginning in 1937 brought him his greatest acclaim during his lifetime. In fact
downloadurl: Hartley began his career in 1909 at Alfred Stieglitz’s 291 gallery as a painter of Maine. Previewing a major exhibition to open in March 2017 at the Met Breuer and in July 2017 at the Colby College Museum of Art
keywords: Randall Griffey illuminates the painter’s dynamic
tags: rich
imageurl: and occasionally contradictory artistic engagement with his native Maine. Maine was to Hartley a springboard to imagination and creative inspiration
presentationdate: a locus of memory and longing
releasedate: a refuge
lastmodified": and a means of communion with previous artists who painted there
column16: especially Winslow Homer. Speaking at the inaugural John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
column19: at the National Gallery of Art
column21: from early post-impressionist interpretations of seasonal change in the region to late
column23:
the state’s great geological landmark. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a generous grant from The Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
description: VI: Rockwell Kent and the End of the World""
thumbnailurl: University of Maine. In November 1937 Life magazine featured four lithographs by the American artist Rockwell Kent (1882-1971) in the article “Four Ways in Which the World May End.” In this lecture from the inaugural John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
playurl: held at the National Gallery of Art on October 22
keywords: Justin Wolff analyzes the so-called “End of the World” lithographs
tags: part of the National Gallery of Art collection
imageurl: in the context of scientific theories about cosmic cataclysm
presentationdate: suspicions that European fascism portended an apocalypse
releasedate: and Kent’s solidarity with a radical leftism that anticipated capitalism’s disintegration. Wolff considers looking beyond their political meaning to what the lithographs tell us about Kent’s renowned emotional intensity and wanderlust—specifically
lastmodified":
what they reveal about his tenacious quest to acquire psychic integrity in barren lands at the ends of the world. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a generous grant from The Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
duration: III: Tableaux in Three Dimensions: Kienholz’s Social Theater at Ferus and Dwan""
thumbnailurl: Max Loehr Collegiate Professor
playurl: University of Michigan. For the public symposium held on November 19
keywords: in conjunction with the exhibition <i>Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
tags: 1959 – 1971 at the National Gallery of Art
imageurl: Alex Potts explains how new exhibition spaces and the experimental staging of work at the Ferus Gallery in Los Angeles and Virginia Dwan’s bicoastal galleries gave Edward Kienholz an opportunity in the early and mid-1960s to realize his large-scale tableaux. The powerful effect these works had on the viewer was not just formal
presentationdate: as in minimalist art
releasedate: or simply a result of their often-provocative
column16: but was also related to deep undercurrents of socially and politically charged content. Eventually this set the tableaux at odds with the prevailing climate of the American art world and its increasingly systematic bracketing of a politics of content in favor of a politics of form. Virginia Dwan’s active promotion of some of Kienholz’s more ambitious
column20:
shown in her exhibition of his concept tableaux in 1967 — testifies to a particularly rich moment in her take-up of new art. Later Kienholz found himself having to shift the installation of ambitious new work from New York and Los Angeles to venues in Europe.

"

title: Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
thumbnailurl: Rhoda Thalhimer Endowed Chair
playurl: Virginia Commonwealth University
downloadurl: and visiting professor
keywords: Yale University. Among twentieth-century artistic styles
tags: minimalism is remarkable for the great number of field theories developed to interpret it. For the public symposium held on November 19
presentationdate: in conjunction with the exhibition <i>Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
releasedate: 1959 – 1971 at the National Gallery of Art
lastmodified": Robert Hobbs analyzes some of the strategies artists employed to avoid interpretation as a primary means for reconsidering minimalism
column16:
using Virginia Dwan’s approach to this art as a starting point.

"

title: Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
duration: VI: Some Art Is Hard to See: Field Trips with Virginia Dwan""
thumbnailurl: department chair of humanities and sciences
playurl: ArtCenter College of Design. For the public symposium held on November 19
keywords: in conjunction with the exhibition <i>Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
tags: 1959 – 1971 at the National Gallery of Art
imageurl: Jane McFadden describes how Virginia Dwan offered pivotal support to artists expanding the field of sculpture beyond the gallery in the late 1960s. Exploring these early endeavors
presentationdate: McFadden considers what unseen histories might emerge from understanding Dwan as a central collaborator in well-known works of land art. By tracing the resonance of key works like Michael Heizer’s Double Negative beyond established interpretations of site and land art
releasedate:
McFadden draws from the shadows the ghosts and other hallucinatory effects of this historical moment that are difficult to see. 

"

title: Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
duration: V: Liberating Artist and Exhibition:  Dwan Gallery and the Reconceptualization of Site""
thumbnailurl: professor of art history
playurl: Savannah College of Art and Design. Supporting her stable of artists and their often-experimental practices remained Virginia Dwan’s primary aim as director of her groundbreaking New York gallery. Along the way
downloadurl: the field-expanding work she promoted required new possibilities for exhibition
keywords: both inside and outside the gallery walls
tags: which advanced notions of site and reimagined the function of the gallery itself. For the public symposium held on November 19
presentationdate: in conjunction with the exhibition <i>Los Angeles to New York: Dwan Gallery
releasedate: 1959 – 1971 at the National Gallery of Art
lastmodified": Emily Taub Webb explores the contributions that Dwan Gallery made to site-oriented practices—including minimalism
column17:
and land art—through close analysis of several exhibitions held between 1967 and 1970.

"

title: Douglas Crimp and Lynne Cooke on """"Before Pictures"""" ""
thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art
playurl: in conversation with Douglas Crimp
downloadurl: art historian
keywords: critic
tags: and Fanny Knapp Allen Professor of Art History and professor of visual and cultural studies
imageurl: University of Rochester. Douglas Crimp is the rare art critic who profoundly influenced a generation of artists. He is best known for his work with the “Pictures Generation”—a name Crimp coined to define the work of artists like Robert Longo and Cindy Sherman
presentationdate: who appropriated images from mass culture to carry out a subversive critique. But while his influence is widely recognized
releasedate: little is known about Crimp’s own formative experiences before the Pictures Generation. On January 8
column16: Douglas Crimp joined Lynne Cooke to discuss the publication of Before Pictures. Part biography and part cultural history
column17:
Before Pictures is a courageous account of an exceptional period in both Crimp’s life and the life of New York City during the late 1960s through the turbulent 1970s.

"

title: Sculpting with Color in Renaissance Florence: An Introduction to the Della Robbia Exhibition
duration: curator of early European sculpture and deputy head of sculpture and decorative arts
language: National Gallery of Art. A new art form emerged in fifteenth-century Florence through the genius of Luca della Robbia
thumbnailurl: exalting the humble material of clay with brilliant modeling and surfaces shining with color that seems to defy time. The first comprehensive exhibition of Della Robbia work in the United States
playurl: originating at the Museum of Fine Arts
downloadurl: Boston and taking new form at the National Gallery of Art
keywords: shows how three generations of Luca's family of skilled artists and entrepreneurs
tags: responding to international demand
imageurl: created magnificent sculpture in glazed terracotta. To celebrate opening day on February 5
releasedate: Alison Luchs explores the human sensitivity
column16: and technical ingenuity that secure the appeal of Della Robbia sculpture into the twenty-first century. Della Robbia: Sculpting with Color in Renaissance Florence is on view through June 4

tags: Tower 2 now boasts the world’s largest display of works by Alexander Calder: more than 40 sculptures and paintings

title: Answering the Search for the Next Ansel Adams
thumbnailurl: National Park Service. In winter 2015
playurl: the National Park Service (NPS) advertised a job listing in search of the next Ansel Adams (1902-1984)
downloadurl: the landscape photographer known for his 1940s NPS commission to document nature as exemplified and protected in US National Parks. The full-time position with the Heritage Documentation Programs (HDP) required experience with large-format photography
keywords: which provides a higher resolution
tags: is more durable than 35mm film
imageurl: and allows the photographer more control to render perspective. The HDP administers the Historic American Buildings Survey (HABS)
presentationdate: the federal government's oldest preservation program
releasedate: and its companion programs: the Historic American Engineering Record (HAER) and Historic American Landscapes Survey (HALS). Documentation produced through the programs constitutes the nation's largest archive of historical architectural
column16: and landscape documentation. The HABS/HAER/HALS collection is housed at the Library of Congress. Milwaukee-native Jarob J. Ortiz was selected for the HDP position out of 5
column17: 000 applicants. In this presentation held on April 18
column19: at the National Gallery of Art
column20:
Ortiz shares the photographs he has taken while serving in this important role.
"

title: “A first-rate collection”: Rodin at the National Gallery of Art
language: Center for Advanced Study in the Visual Arts
thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art. The Simpson Collection at the National Gallery of Art is one of the few remaining private collections assembled with the participation of artist Auguste Rodin (1840-1917). The centenary of Rodin’s death offers an occasion to examine the large number of works that Katherine Seney Simpson and John W. Simpson
playurl: the first American collectors to meet Rodin
downloadurl: gave to the Gallery in 1942. In this lecture recorded on May 5
tags: Antoinette Le Normand-Romain provides an overview of the Simpson collection of drawings and sculptures in bronze
imageurl: marble
presentationdate: terracotta
releasedate: and plaster
lastmodified": including Rodin’s portrait of Mrs. Simpson. The Gallery has benefitted since from the generosity of other donors
column17: as Yale University art historian Charles Seymour Jr. stated
column18:
“a first-rate collection” of works by Rodin. 

"

title: John Moran and Art Photography in America: 1855–1875
duration: historian of photography and American culture. The first exhibition to focus exclusively on photographs made in the eastern half of the United States during the 19th century
language: East of the Mississippi: Nineteenth-Century American Landscape Photography showcases some 175 works—from daguerreotypes and stereographs to albumen prints and cyanotypes—as well as several photographers whose efforts have often gone unheralded. Mary Panzer shares the story of one photographer
thumbnailurl: John Moran (1831-1902)
playurl: brother to painter Thomas Moran
downloadurl: in this lecture held on May 14
tags: at the National Gallery of Art. John Moran belonged to a network of Philadelphia-based amateur artists
imageurl: historians
presentationdate: scientists
releasedate: and collectors who recognized photography as a fine art in the years before the Civil War. Moran also appreciated the art of the newly developed stereograph. After 1865 the art of John Moran “disappeared” into collections of prints and historic documents
lastmodified": while Philadelphia photographers continued to lead the country in excellence for another generation. East of the Mississippi is on view from March 12 through July 16

title: Restoration/REVELATION: The Exterior Wings of the Ghent Altarpiece
thumbnailurl: Royal Institute for Cultural Heritage (KIK-IRPA). The Ghent Altarpiece (1432) by Jan and Hubert van Eyck is one of the most iconic works of Western art as it embodies the birth of new skills and vision. Still housed in Saint Bavo Cathedral
playurl: Ghent
downloadurl: Belgium
keywords: the site for which it was created
tags: The Ghent Altarpiece (or Mystic Lamb as it is sometimes referred to) has undergone conservation and restoration treatment overseen by the Royal Institute for Cultural Heritage (KIK-IRPA
imageurl: Brussels) since 2012. No one expected this restoration to turn into a revelation: the real Van Eyck had been hidden beneath overpaint for centuries! In this lecture recorded on June 2
releasedate: at the National Gallery of Art
lastmodified": Bart Devolder shares remarkable discoveries from the first phase of treatment
column16:
and previews findings from the ongoing second phase. This program is made possible by the Henry and Alice H. Greenwald Endowment Fund for Conservation.

"

title: Wyeth Foundation for American Art Symposium 2017: Artists Panel: The African American Art World in Twentieth-Century Washington
thumbnailurl: David C. Driskell
playurl: Sam Gilliam
downloadurl: Keith A. Morrison
keywords: Martin Puryear
tags: Sylvia Snowden
imageurl: and Lou Stovall; Ruth Fine
presentationdate: moderator and former curator of special projects in modern art
releasedate: National Gallery of Art. In this program
column17: eight distinguished artists discuss their careers and relationships as members of the Washington
column19: art world. Panelists are Lilian Thomas Burwell
column27: former curator of special projects in modern art
column30:
which was part of a two-day symposium at the National Gallery of Art. The program was organized by the Center for Advanced Study in the Visual Arts in collaboration with the Howard University Gallery of Art and was supported by the Wyeth Foundation for American Art.

"

title: Edvard Munch: Spiritualism
thumbnailurl: independent scholar
playurl: and Elizabeth Prelinger
downloadurl: Keyser Family Professor of Art History and Modern Art
keywords: Georgetown University
tags: in conversation with Mollie Berger
imageurl: curatorial assistant
presentationdate: department of prints and drawings
releasedate: National Gallery of Art. This conversation
column17: in conjunction with the exhibition Edvard Munch: Color in Context
column18: aims to connect the highly charged and personal art of Edvard Munch (1863–1944) with contemporary notions of spirituality. Mollie Berger
column20: and Elizabeth Prelinger explore how theosophy influenced Munch’s art
column21: specifically his use of color. In addition
column22: the discussion examines the ways in which advances in various scientific fields impacted the spread of spiritualism and how artists responded to these cultural shifts. Edvard Munch: Color in Context is on view at the National Gallery of Art from September 3

title: Steps toward Reality: Matthias Mansen in Conversation with John Tyson
thumbnailurl: assistant professor of art
playurl: University of Massachusetts Boston. Born in 1958 in Ravensburg
downloadurl: Germany
keywords: Matthias Mansen studied painting with Georg Baselitz and Markus LÃ¼pertz at Staatliche Akademie der Bildenden KÃ¼nste Karlsruhe. Although he trained as a painter
tags: Mansen shifted his focus exclusively to printmaking in the second half of the 1980s. He advances the tradition of woodblock printing by transforming pieces of scavenged wood into printing blocks
imageurl: which he progressively carves and recarves
presentationdate: using them to create large-scale compositions. The special installation Matthias Mansen: Configurations
releasedate: on view in the West Concourse Gallery from July 23 through December 13
column16: presents 13 woodcuts from the collection of the National Gallery of Art. John Tyson curated the installation during his Andrew W. Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship at the Gallery. In this conversation
column19: Mansen and Tyson discuss the artist’s career
column21:
and the impact of research—into subjects from cartography to the US Exploring Expedition—on his artworks. Mansen lives and works in Berlin.

"

title: More than Mimicry: The Parrot in Dutch Genre Painting
description: The newly independent Dutch Republic established a vast and profitable trade network in the 17th century. Among the most coveted of the impressive luxury imports was the parrot. Beautiful
thumbnailurl: parrots become a mainstay in Dutch genre paintings. Their presence in these works is
playurl: however
downloadurl: more than ostentatious display. These very social and intelligent creatures were highly valued companions. The interaction between parrots and people gave Dutch genre painters an unprecedented opportunity for creativity and candor
keywords: upon which they skillfully capitalized. In this lecture held on December 26 at the National Gallery of Art
tags: Kristen Gonzalez traces the iconography of these birds in the history of art and highlights the departure from tradition evident in their depiction in the Dutch Golden Age. This lecture accompanies the landmark exhibition Vermeer and the Masters of Genre Painting: Inspiration and Rivalry

thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art. The paintings that portray daily life in the Dutch Republic in the 17th century often include images of alcohol
playurl: be it wine or beer. Scenes of festive dinners and boisterous parties in taverns suggest that alcohol flowed freely
downloadurl: whereas in some depictions of intimate gatherings the presence of a single glass of wine merely hints at drinking. In other genre scenes signs of alcohol are totally absent. This lecture
keywords: given on October 14
imageurl: by Henriette Rahusen
presentationdate: poses a number of questions: Did the Dutch imbibe with gusto or nip with restraint? Were they so wretchedly frugal in all things
releasedate: excepting alcohol
lastmodified": as the paintings and historical records suggest? This lecture is in conjunction with the landmark exhibition Vermeer and the Masters of Genre Painting: Inspiration and Rivalry
column20: The exhibition examines the artistic exchanges among Johannes Vermeer and his contemporaries from the mid-1650s to around 1680
column21:
when they reached the height of their technical ability and mastery of genre painting.
"

title: Pictures in Paintings
duration: Senior Lecturer and Manager of Gallery Talks and Lectures for Adults
language: Department of Education. Dutch 17th-century homes typically would have included a variety of wall decorations
thumbnailurl: including curtains
playurl: mirrors
downloadurl: and pictures. Many specialists in genre painting represented interiors with paintings and prints of recognizable subjects. These pictures within pictures are sometimes
keywords: though not always
tags: a significant clue as to the interpretation of a painting. This lecture
imageurl: given by Eric Denker on December 19
releasedate: at the National Gallery of Art
lastmodified": explores the added or reinforced symbolism of these depictions in the context of the genre painting of Vermeer and his contemporaries. The symbolic use of mirrors is also considered. This lecture is in conjunction with the landmark exhibition Vermeer and the Masters of Genre Painting: Inspiration and Rivalry—on view from October 22
column18: 2018—which examines the artistic exchanges among Johannes Vermeer and his contemporaries from the mid-1650s to around 1680
column19:
when they reached the height of their technical ability and mastery of genre painting.

"

title: Innovation
duration: and Fine Painting Technique: Marketing High-Life Style in the Dutch 17th Century""
thumbnailurl: research conservator
playurl: National Gallery of Art
downloadurl: and Lisha Glinsman
keywords: conservation scientist
tags: National Gallery of Art. Recent technical research at the National Gallery of Art explores artistic exchange among the painters featured in the exhibition Vermeer and the Masters of Genre Painting: Inspiration and Rivalry
imageurl: on view from October 22
releasedate: through January 21
lastmodified": 2018. In this lecture held on October 30
column17: as part of the Works in Progress series
column18: Melanie Gifford and Lisha Glinsman share discoveries from their research. Study reveals that these elegant scenes
column19: painted for an elite Dutch art market
column20: shared physical characteristics that defined a collective “high-life” style. At the same time
column21: the research shows that painters each marketed their works by cultivating a distinctive personal manner and that
column22: through subtle variations of technique and materials
column23: they could sell at somewhat different price levels. Finally
column24: technical study offers direct evidence for 17th century artists’ evaluations of their contemporaries’ artistic style: the recognizable features they selected and quoted in their own works for the amusement of sophisticated collectors. Gifford and Glinsman’s essay
column25: “Collective Style and Personal Manner: Materials and Techniques of High-Life Genre Painting
column26:
” published in the exhibition catalogue explores these issues in detail.

"

title: Introduction to the Exhibition-Sally Mann: A Thousand Crossings
thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art. For more than forty years
playurl: Sally Mann (b. 1951
downloadurl: Lexington
keywords: Virginia) has made experimental
tags: elegiac
imageurl: and hauntingly beautiful photographs—a broad body of work that includes figure studies
presentationdate: still lifes
releasedate: and landscapes. Offering both a sweeping overview of Mann’s artistic achievement and a focused exploration of the continuing influence of the South on her work
lastmodified": the exhibition Sally Mann: A Thousand Crossings presents some 115 photographs
column16: many of which have not been exhibited or published previously. This powerful and provocative work is organized into five sections: Family
column20: and What Remains. On view from March 4 through May 28
column22: the exhibition is accompanied by a fully illustrated catalog with essays that explore the development of Mann’s art; her family photographs; the landscape as repository of personal
column24:
and racial memory; and her debt to 19th-century photographers and techniques. Sarah Greenough celebrates the exhibition with this introductory lecture recorded on opening day.

"

title: Introduction to the Exhibition-Michel Sittow: Estonian Painter at the Courts of Renaissance Europe
language: National Gallery of Art. Undoubtedly the greatest Renaissance artist from Estonia
thumbnailurl: Michel Sittow (c. 1469-1525) was born in Reval (now Tallinn in present-day Estonia)
playurl: quite likely studied in Bruges with Hans Memling
downloadurl: and worked at the courts of renowned European royals such as King Ferdinand of Aragon and Queen Isabella of Castile. Organized by the Art Museum of Estonia
keywords: Tallinn
tags: and the National Gallery of Art
imageurl: the exhibition Michel Sittow: Estonian Painter at the Courts of Renaissance Europe marks the occasion of the centennial of the Estonian Republic in 2018. On view at the Gallery from January 28 through May 13
releasedate: the exhibition represents most of Sittow's small oeuvre through some 20 works. In this lecture held on March 11
lastmodified": John Hand examines Sittow's art in a broader context
column16:
including his relationship to Netherlandish contemporaries and a possible collaboration with Juan de Flandes.
"

title: Carrie Mae Weems: Kitchen Table Series
duration: artist. Made only a few years after Carrie Mae Weems received her MFA in 1984 from the University of California
thumbnailurl: Kitchen Table Series consists of 20 staged photographs depicting Weems and others seated at a table. Endowed with a keen sense of how to transform her body into an expressive tool
playurl: Weems used the photographs to tell the story of a woman’s life as seen through the intimate space of the kitchen—the traditional sphere of women and a site of sanctuary
downloadurl: creation
keywords: shared experiences
tags: and emotional honesty. In this performance held on February 6
presentationdate: in conjunction with the installation of Kitchen Table Series in the East Building of the National Gallery of Art

including images from Grace Notes: Reflections for Now performed recently at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. This program is made possible by the James D. and Kathryn K. Steele Fund for Photography.

title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Palette: Rebecca Strand and Georgia O’Keeffe in New Mexico
duration: Kristin and Roger Servison Curator Emerita of American Paintings
thumbnailurl: Boston. In 1929
playurl: Georgia O’Keeffe and Rebecca Strand left their homes and famous photographer-husbands to travel to New Mexico in search of artistic independence. O’Keeffe was established by that time but often felt constrained by the artistic circle around Alfred Stieglitz. Beck Strand was trying to find her way as a painter in the shadow of Paul Strand’s growing success and in a community that seemed to have room for only one woman artist. Strand had a little-sister relationship with O’Keeffe
downloadurl: often dressing and wearing her hair like her better-known friend.  During the two summers they spent in Taos
keywords: O’Keeffe provided Strand with the support she needed to develop an independent artistic voice and a medium—painting on glass—that she could call her own. For Strand
tags: who settled there permanently in 1933
imageurl: Taos offered an environment that suited both her swashbuckling public persona and her delicate imagery. In this lecture held on March 18
releasedate: at the National Gallery of Art
column17:
the Southwest offered a space where women artists could flourish.
"

title: Parrots and People in Dutch Genre Paintings: A Discussion with Dr. Irene Pepperberg on the Role of the African Grey Parrot in the 17th Century
thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art; Irene Pepperberg
playurl: lecturer and research associate
downloadurl: department of psychology
keywords: Harvard University
tags: senior lecturer
imageurl: Brain and Cognitive Sciences
presentationdate: MIT
releasedate: president
lastmodified": the Alex Foundation. The parrot was among many coveted imports to the northern Netherlands in the Golden Age
column16: and its prominence in genre paintings of the period has generated interest not only among art historians
column17: but also in the scientific community. In an interview on January 10
column20: curatorial assistant of northern baroque paintings
column22: Harvard scientist and renowned expert on animal cognition
column23: discuss the lively interactions between parrots and people in Dutch paintings
column24: some of which were examined during the landmark exhibition Vermeer and the Masters of Genre Painting: Inspiration and Rivalry. Pepperberg’s work with the African grey parrot has revolutionized ideas about animal communication and intelligence. Examining a number of Dutch genre paintings that depict parrots
column25: Pepperberg and Gonzalez explore the role of these beloved family companions from a unique
column26: multidisciplinary perspective. Their analysis considers a society that not only recognized the cognitive abilities of parents
column27: but also documented these abilities in paintings of the highest caliber. Their paintings fetched large sums of money and provided an elite clientele exactly what they wanted—a reflection of their society’s sophistication and ideals. Pepperberg and Gonzalez consider the parrot and its place then and now
column28:
and reveal striking similarities in animal-human relationships throughout history.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
thumbnailurl: department of American and British paintings
playurl: National Gallery of Art. When the National Gallery of Art opened in 1941
downloadurl: only ten American paintings were on view. Almost all were portraits. Of these
keywords: only one was of a woman—the regal Catherine Brass Yates by Gilbert Stuart. Elegantly dressed in white silk
tags: Mrs. Yates represents the essence of elite society in America following the Revolution. Seventy-five years later
imageurl: another portrait of a woman in white has joined the collection. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
presentationdate: held on March 23
lastmodified": at the National Gallery of Art
column16: Nancy Anderson shares how Archibald John Motley Jr.’s moving portrait of his grandmother
column19:
speaks to a very different American story. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
description: Part 2 Inspiring Visits with Archibald Motley Jr. ""
thumbnailurl: curator
playurl: and Distinguished University Professor of Art
downloadurl: Emeritus
keywords: University of Maryland at College Park. Archibald Motley Jr.’s paintings of African American subjects underwent drastic changes in style and reception during the artist’s long lifetime. After including Motley’s paintings in his Two Centuries of Black American Art exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 1976
tags: David Driskell visited Motley at his home in 1979 and 1980. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
imageurl: held on March 23
releasedate: at the National Gallery of Art
lastmodified":
David Driskell presents his recollections of those conversations as well as other impressions of Motley’s work formed during Driskell’s career as an art historian and curator. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
description: Part 3: Politics and Pageantry: “The Greek Slave” in the Capital City ""
thumbnailurl: department of American and British paintings
playurl: National Gallery of Art. Sarah Cash presents a brief history of Hiram Powers’s marble sculpture The Greek Slave at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
downloadurl: held on March 23
tags: at the National Gallery of Art. In particular
imageurl: Cash considers the work’s changing display and reception
presentationdate: both public and private
releasedate: in Washington
lastmodified":
DC from 1848 onward. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
language: ” and the Politics of Sculptural Reproduction""
thumbnailurl: R. Tess Korobkin
playurl: PhD candidate
downloadurl: history of art
keywords: Yale University
tags: and Ellen Holtzman Fellow
imageurl: Luce/ACLS Dissertation Fellowship in American Art
presentationdate: 2017–2018. The fact that Frederick Douglass
releasedate: a former slave and an outspoken proponent of abolitionism
lastmodified": owned a statuette of Hiram Powers’s The Greek Slave raises difficult questions. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
column18: at the National Gallery of Art
column19:
Tess Korobkin highlights other examples of reproductions of the sculpture in a range of media to more fully explore the layered and sometimes contradictory political materialities of Powers’s work. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
thumbnailurl: Karen Lemmey
playurl: curator of sculpture
downloadurl: Smithsonian American Art Museum. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
keywords: held on March 23
imageurl: at the National Gallery of Art
presentationdate: Karen Lemmey draws together the two replicas of The Greek Slave commissioned by William Humble Ward: one completed in 1846 and preserved in the Corcoran Collection at the National Gallery of Art
releasedate: the other completed in 1848 and lost since the early 20th century. Sculptor Hiram Powers cleverly satisfied Lord Ward’s insistent demands for a unique version of the famed composition
lastmodified":
revealing his ability to simultaneously entice and manage his patron’s desires. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
language: and George Bellows at the National Gallery of Art ""
thumbnailurl: Charles Brock
playurl: associate curator
downloadurl: department of American and British paintings
keywords: National Gallery of Art. When Both Members of This Club by George Bellows was placed on view at the National Gallery of Art in January 1945 at the behest of Gallery benefactor Chester Dale
tags: it became the first significant work by an American modernist painter to be featured in the permanent collection. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
imageurl: held on March 23
releasedate: at the National Gallery of Art
lastmodified":
Charles Brock discusses how this unsettling depiction of a violent interracial boxing match was acquired when there was little American or modern painting of any kind at the Gallery and established an important precedent for later efforts to better represent the diverse achievements of American modernism. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
description: Part 7: “You put your self in his place”: George Bellows and the Limits of Bodily Knowledge ""
thumbnailurl: department of English literature
playurl: University of Birmingham. Robert Henri was referring to a cadaver he and his brother had just dissected when he confessed in an 1886 diary entry: “You put your self in his place.” Over the next two decades Henri developed and taught an approach to painting the body that emphasized breathing
downloadurl: feeling
keywords: and moving with one’s subject in reciprocal exchange. George Bellows
tags: one of his students
imageurl: embodied Henri’s theories in his fleshy
presentationdate: intuitive art
releasedate: drawing on the experience of his own athletic body to picture the raw physicality of street kids
column16: and boxers. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
column19: at the National Gallery of Art
column20:
John Fagg explores the possibilities and limits of Bellows’s painting as a way to know and represent the bodies and lives of others. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
description: Part 8: Invitation: Audience Engagement and the Changing Role of Arts Professionals ""
thumbnailurl: Holly Bass|360. At the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
playurl: held on March 23
keywords: at the National Gallery of Art
tags: local artist Holly Bass discusses the importance of audience engagement as it relates to her current practice and the larger national conversation on equity
imageurl: diversity
presentationdate:
and inclusion. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
thumbnailurl: department of modern prints and drawings
playurl: National Gallery of Art. Recent additions to the Gallery’s collection have sparked new discussions and new ways of thinking about “fine” art. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
downloadurl: held on March 23
tags: at the National Gallery of Art
imageurl: Judith Brodie looks at some examples
presentationdate: including works by Winsor McCay
releasedate: Saul Steinberg
column16:
and considers how they both challenge and conform to established thinking and in what way they reshape the conversation. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
thumbnailurl: photographer
playurl: landscape architect
downloadurl: and Cecil and Ida Green Professor of Landscape Architecture and Planning
keywords: Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Many of Dorothea Lange’s photographs from the recent
tags: important gift of Daniel Greenberg and Susan Steinhauser appear in her books An American Exodus: A Record of Human Erosion (1939) and The American Country Woman (1967)
imageurl: in which she paired photographs to expand meaning. Speaking at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art
presentationdate: held on March 23
lastmodified": at the National Gallery of Art
column16: Anne Whiston Spirn looks at a selection of images from this collection in the context of the pair to which they belong and the captions that Lange wrote for them. “I used to think in terms of single photographs. The Bull’s-eye technique. No more. A photographic statement is what I now reach for. Therefore these pairs
column17: like a statement of 2 words.” By the time she wrote this in 1958 Lange had been experimenting with pairing
column19:
and captions for more than two decades. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
thumbnailurl: department of academic programs
playurl: National Gallery of Art. In the poem “Joy
downloadurl: ” Poet Laureate of the United States Tracy K. Smith describes the body alternately as memory
keywords: as appetite
tags: and as this question: “What do you believe in?” Using works from the Gallery’s collection as examples
imageurl: Terence Washington
presentationdate: at the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art held on March 23
releasedate: 2018 at the National Gallery of Art
lastmodified": considers different ways the body has been framed in American art. How have the nation’s artists articulated responses to the body’s question? What is at stake in the presentation of those answers here
column16:
in the nation’s gallery? The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art 2018
thumbnailurl: 1975–present
playurl: National Gallery of Art
downloadurl: in conversation with artists Janine Antoni
keywords: Byron Kim
tags: and Glenn Ligon. At the second annual John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art held on March 23
imageurl: 2018 at the National Gallery of Art
presentationdate: Janine Antoni
releasedate: Byron Kim
column16: whose works are featured in the special installation Bodies of Work
column17:
discuss their art with Molly Donovan. The conversation rounded out the symposium’s focus on portraiture and the histories and processes of representing the human figure in the nation’s collection. The John Wilmerding Symposium on American Art is made possible by a grant from the Walton Family Foundation.

"

title: Mathematics and the Art of M. C. Escher
language: Moravian College. Held in conjunction with the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics annual meeting and the 120th anniversary of the birth of Dutch artist M. C. Escher (1898–1972)
thumbnailurl: this lecture considers how the imagery in Escher’s graphic works makes use of geometry and often provides visual metaphors for abstract mathematical concepts. Recorded at the National Gallery of Art on April 25
downloadurl: Doris J. Schattschneider examines these concepts implicit in several of Escher’s works
keywords: outlines some of the geometry that governs his interlocking figures
tags: and reveals how this “math anxious” artist performed pioneering mathematical research in order to accomplish his artistic goals. Escher’s mathematical curiosity and insight have been the inspiration for many mathematicians
imageurl: scientists
presentationdate:
and contemporary artists who seek solutions to problems (both mathematical and artistic) first posed by Escher himself.

"

title: German Expressionism and Degenerate Art
language: National Gallery of Art. Germany around 1900 was a volatile contradiction—modernizing rapidly
thumbnailurl: yet deeply conservative in values. This was fertile ground for the birth of German expressionism represented by the paintings and sculptures of Ernst Barlach
playurl: Max Beckmann
downloadurl: Ernst Ludwig Kirchner
keywords: Franz Marc
tags: Otto MÃ¼ller
imageurl: Emil Nolde
presentationdate: and others. With the rise of national socialism in the 1930s in Germany
releasedate: many of these avant-garde artists and the movements of which they were a part came to be labeled “degenerate.” The recent gift of the Arnold and Joan Saltzman collection of German expressionist art has transformed the Gallery’s holdings of modern art in this area. In this lecture presented on May 4
column16: at the National Gallery of Art
column17: senior lecturer David Gariff explores the nature of German expressionist art against the backdrop of two important exhibitions mounted by the Nazis in 1937: <i>The Great German Art Exhibition
column20: on July 19. Through these two exhibitions and their related documents and propaganda
column21: the Nazis sought to establish and support the reputation of the approved art of the Third Reich
column22:
while at the same time to unleash a destructive “tornado” (as Hitler referred to it) against modern art.

"

title: Picturing Alexander Hamilton
duration: guest lecturer. Coinciding with the Kennedy Center’s production of the Broadway musical Hamilton
language: guest lecturer Heidi Applegate surveys works of art featuring Alexander Hamilton in this presentation delivered August 5
playurl: at the National Gallery of Art. The American painter John Trumbull and the Italian sculptor Giuseppe Cerrachi are Hamilton’s best known portraitists thanks to the countless reproductions of their works made after Hamilton’s death. Several other artists also created portraits of Hamilton from life
downloadurl: many of which were replicated during the 19th century. Applegate also discusses portraits of Hamilton’s family members and other founding fathers who were important to Hamilton’s political career

as well as the major posthumous paintings and monuments that helped to secure Hamilton’s legacy.

title: Pop without Pretense: Mass Media and the Art of James Castle
duration: Andrew W. Mellon Postdoctoral Curatorial Fellow
language: departments of American and British paintings and American and modern prints and drawings
thumbnailurl: National Gallery of Art. Self-taught artist James Castle (1899–1977) lived in remote rural Idaho until moving to the outskirts of Boise in his thirties. Not only was he isolated geographically
playurl: he was also born deaf. For Castle—like many “outsider” artists—past scholarship used biography and his marginalized social status to interpret his work. On December 3
keywords: as part of the Works in Progress series at the National Gallery of Art
tags: Diana Greenwald argues that the progressive integration of visual culture—nationally and globally—is key to understanding this artist’s work. Greenwald considers Castle through the same art historical lens applied to mainstream artists of the period who were similarly engaged with mass-circulated visual culture. Classifying Castle as a pop artist
imageurl: although one without the pretense to distinguish “high” from “low” visual sources
presentationdate:
moves away from the myth-making rhetoric that pervades discussion about outsider artists and makes an important contribution to the literature.

"

title: Fifteenth-Century Florentine and Tuscan Sculpture in the National Gallery of Art
language: National Gallery of Art Italian sculpture of the 15th century in Florence and Tuscany
thumbnailurl: departed from the elegant
playurl: decorative style of the earlier Gothic period to reflect a greater admiration for
downloadurl: and understanding of
keywords: the strength and structure of the human body. In this respect
tags: Renaissance sculptors emulated the ideals of the ancient Greeks and Romans when depicting contemporary or Christian subjects. Sculptors like Donatello
imageurl: Desiderio da Settignano
presentationdate: Mino da Fiesole
releasedate: Bernardo and Antonio Rossellino
column18: revived a classical interest in the human body depicted in full-length figures demonstrating naturalism and ease of movement. Relief sculptures explored new effects of light and atmosphere. Displaying a variety of materials including marble
column22: and ceramic; and a range of processes from carving to modeling to casting
column23: 15th-century Florentine sculpture served a variety of secular and religious purposes. It also became a model for the many talented Italian sculptors to follow
column24: most notably the young Michelangelo. In this lecture presented on October 22
column26: at the National Gallery of Art

title: A Conversation with Richard Mosse
thumbnailurl: senior curator and head of the department of photographs
playurl: National Gallery of Art
downloadurl: and Andrea Nelson
keywords: associate curator of photographs
tags: National Gallery of Art Irish photographer Richard Mosse (b. 1980) attempts to capture the complex realities of loss and destruction. Having gained initial recognition and acclaim for his work on the conflict in the Democratic Republic of the Congo
imageurl: Mosse became increasingly frustrated with the constraints of conventional documentary photography. In an attempt to refresh the medium and reengage viewers
presentationdate: Mosse began using a military-grade surveillance camera
releasedate: focusing on migrants and refugee camps. Locating his subjects and creating images through thermal radiation
lastmodified": Mosse subverts the aggression of the military technology to reveal the hardships of those displaced by war. This work culminated in the 52-minute video Incoming
column16: filmed by Trevor Tweeten with a score by Ben Frost
column17: that vacillates between scenes of the profoundly beautiful and the meditative
column18: the terrifying and the horrific. In conjunction with the installation opening at the National Gallery of Art on November 17
column20: Mosse discusses this narrative of displacement and migration in a conversation with curators Sarah Greenough and Andrea Nelson. Incoming is on view through March 22

which was made possible by the support of the president and other government officials; acknowledges the generosity of others who supported his father’s vision; and commends the contributions of individuals and craftsmen involved in the building’s construction.
