title: Reflections on the Collection: The Edmond J. Safra Visiting Professors at the National Gallery of Art: David Bomford on Ãdouard Manet’s The Railway (1873)
thumbnailurl: and 2018 Edmond J. Safra Visiting Professor at the National Gallery of Art) discusses the importance of  Ãdouard Manet’s The Railway (1873)

title: Episode 1: Lara Downes and """"Tomorrow I May Be Far Away""""""
description: Art meets us where we are. For classical pianist and activist Lara Downes
duration: Romare Bearden’s collage parallels her own life and family story: a puzzle full of questions and unfinished business. On her journey inside Bearden’s work
language: Downes travels backward to explore Black memory. In response to the collage
thumbnailurl: she brings together different musical sources
playurl: overlaying sounds that sit together comfortably at times and create tension at others
downloadurl:
giving them the freedom to coexist.

"

title: Episode 2: Daniel Bernard Roumain and """"American Gothic""""""
language: and enduring hope in this famous photograph of Ella Watson
thumbnailurl: one of many by Gordon Parks. Performance poet Lady Caress describes it as “the physical form of stolen expectations.” Together
playurl: they respond to the iconic photograph with a combination of music and poetry. In the ebb and flow of his composition
downloadurl:
DBR hopes to capture the rhythm of Watson’s life—an elegy for someone he longs to have known.

"

title: Episode 3: Bora Yoon and """"Ommah""""""
language: ” as the title of his final video sculpture. For composer and multi-instrumentalist Bora Yoon
thumbnailurl: this evokes the mother tongue and the motherland. Through the concept of cultural blood memory
playurl:
Yoon explores whether we carry the sounds and memories of our people within us. She responds to Paik’s work by bringing together traditional Korean instruments and her own eclectic electronic music.

"

title: Episode 4: Jasiri X and Kerry James Marshall’s “Untitled (Man)”
description:
Hip-hop artist Jasiri X looks at Kerry James Marshall’s woodcut almost like he’s looking into a mirror. It captures the experience of a Black man: resilient but restrained from being his authentic self. Jasiri responds to the work through two songs that reflect on his internal struggle. 
"

title: Episode 5: Kamala Sankaram and Mark Rothko’s “Untitled”
duration: composer Kamala Sankaram was drawn to Mark Rothko’s painting: it both captured her grief and calmed her. That experience influenced Sankaram’s approach to creating a musical score
language:
which she shares in this episode.

"

title: ""El Rio de Luz (The River of Light)

description: Narrated by Isabella Rossellini and produced by the National Gallery of Art
duration: this film traces the career of Giuseppe Arcimboldo
language: an artist whose work thrilled and delighted the Habsburg courts of the later 16th century. Arcimboldo was best known for his "composite heads"—faces composed of fruits
thumbnailurl: vegetables
playurl: fish
downloadurl: flowers
keywords: and beasts of all kinds. The film explores the connection between his paintings and the burgeoning natural sciences

description: This excerpt is from a documentary produced by the National Gallery of Art that includes archival footage of Edward Hopper (1882–1967)
duration: new footage of places that inspired him in New York and New England
language: including his boyhood home in Nyack and his studio on Washington Square

playurl: this film traces Hopper's varied influences
downloadurl:
from French impressionism to the gangster films of the 1930s. Artists Red Grooms and Eric Fischl discuss Hopper's influence on their careers. title: Edward Hopper's New York
description: The National Gallery of Art has released a new video podcast about the artist and his work and influence. In the podcast

thumbnailurl: New England

title: Arshile Gorky: Ararat (Excerpts)
description: Years after campaigns against minority Armenians in Turkey caused his family to disperse and his mother to die before his eyes
duration: Gorky found a 1912 photograph taken in the city of Van upon which he based drawn and painted portraits of The Artist and His Mother. The video Ararat (Excerpts) investigates the fraught history of Gorky's lost childhood through his protracted work on the image of himself at age twelve
language:
standing beside his mother Shushan. Derived from the feature-length film Ararat written and directed by Academy AwardÂ®-nominated director Atom Egoyan.

title: From Impressionism to Modernism: The Chester Dale Collection
duration: Chester Dale started out as a Wall Street messenger in the early 20th century. By 1910 he was poised to make the fortune that enabled him to assemble one of the finest collections of modern art in America. He and his wife Maud first focused on American paintings
language: but they soon turned their attention to French art of the 19th and early 20th centuries
thumbnailurl: acquiring a few old masters along the way. Dale's gifts to the nation
playurl: numbering more than 300 works of art
downloadurl: transformed the Gallery's collection and included masterpieces by Manet
keywords: Monet
tags: Renoir
imageurl: and Picasso. Never lent to other museums
presentationdate:
these paintings can only be seen at the National Gallery of Art. Narrated by director Earl A. Powell III.

"

title: Rachel Whiteread: """"Ghost""""""
duration: Rachel Whiteread created a positive from a negative
language: making a plaster cast of the interior "void" of a Victorian parlor measuring approximately 9 feet wide
thumbnailurl: 11 1/2 feet high
playurl: and 10 feet deep. Whiteread has said of this sculpture that she was trying to "mummify the air in the room
downloadurl: " hence the title. Whiteread created Ghost over a period of three months in an abandoned building at 486 Archway Road
keywords: North London
tags: covering the interior walls with multiple plaster molds
imageurl: each about five inches thick. When the plaster dried
presentationdate:
she peeled the molds from the walls and reassembled them on a steel frame. In this interview Whiteread discusses the process of making Ghost and lends new insight to her work.

title: Turner on the Tyne
description:
The moon rises high over water and becomes one with Turner's evocative image of the sights and sounds on the River Tyne at Newcastle. Time-lapse photography interweaves with close details of Turner's painting to capture both the stillness of the night and the work of loading coals by moonlight and torch.

"

title: The Lions of Peter Paul Rubens

duration: illustrated in the famous Old Testament story of Daniel in the lions' den and in Peter Paul Rubens' full-scale painting at the National Gallery. Daniel's travail in a closed cave unfolds here through a series of comparative frames: Rubens' preparatory drawings
language: painted lions with human bones at their feet
thumbnailurl: and footage of actual lions
playurl:
similar to those Rubens saw at the royal menagerie in Brussels.

title: Talk About Art
description: Talk About Art is a six-minute documentary film that highlights visitors to the National Gallery of Art in Washington
duration: DC. Among the visitors who share their thoughts on art are people from all walks of life—including students
thumbnailurl: an architect
playurl: a security guard
downloadurl: and a hairdresser. These are not art historians
keywords: but art is a common bond for them
tags:
and definitely a force in their lives. For some art is a way to connect to the past; for others it is a way to see the world around them in a different way. Listening to their side of the museum experience may get you talking about art as well.

"

title: In the Tower: Mark Rothko
language: was produced by the National Gallery of Art in conjunction with the exhibition In the Tower: Mark Rothko. The film considers Rothko's style
thumbnailurl: which infused abstract painting with emotional significance. Recognized in the 1950s for his use of brilliant colors
playurl: Rothko changed direction in the 1960s and produced a series of canvases known as the black-form paintings. Critics and artists often associated the darkness of these works with Rothko's bouts of illness and depression
downloadurl:
but Cooper argues that the paintings are a continuation of the painter's lifelong exploration of light.

"

title: Wyeth Lecture in American Art 2009: Minstrelsy """"Uncorked"""": Thomas Eakins' Empathetic Realism""
language: this podcast presents the fourth Wyeth Lecture in American Art
thumbnailurl: a biennial event hosted by the Center for Advanced Study in the Visual Arts and supported by the Wyeth Foundation for American Art. Richard J. Powell focuses on Thomas Eakins (1844–1916) as uniquely empathetic among the many 19th-century artists who depicted African American performance and entertainment. Eakins' Negro Boy Dancing (1887; Metropolitan Museum of Art) shows a young banjo player
playurl: an elderly teacher
downloadurl: and an adolescent dancer
keywords: evoking the American rage for the form of musical theater known as minstrelsy. Eakins' watercolor
tags: along with two oil-on-board studies at the National Gallery of Art
imageurl: challenged the tendency of minstrelsy to employ racial ridicule and physical exaggeration. Instead
presentationdate: Powell argues
releasedate:
Eakins adhered to a painterly realism as well as his own brand of empathy and ethics.

title: Brice Marden in the Studio

language: was produced by the National Gallery of Art in conjunction with the exhibition Joan MirÃ³: The Ladder of Escape. Joan MirÃ³ was passionately committed to his native Catalonia and its struggle for independence from Spain. But he also longed to escape into artistic freedom. This tension drove his art in strange and beautiful ways. MirÃ³ was by turns influenced by Dada

title: Ann Hamilton
description: Ann Hamilton presented a lecture on her nearly 30-year career as part of the Diamonstein-Spielvogel Lecture Series at the National Gallery of Art on September 16
duration: 2011. Hamilton has made multimedia installations with stunning qualities and quantities of materials: a room lined with small canvas dummies
language: a table spread with human and animal teeth
thumbnailurl: the artist herself wearing a man's suit covered in a layer of thousands of toothpicks. Along the way
playurl: she has constantly set and reset the course of contemporary art. Often using sound
downloadurl: found objects
keywords: and the spoken and written word

presentationdate: language

description: Photographer Garry Winogrand (1928–1984) is known for his sweeping portrait of American life during the postwar decades. His photographs powerfully combine the hope and exhilaration as well as the anxiety and turbulence that characterized America during these vital years

title: Wyeth Lecture in American Art 2013: Reversing American Art
description: In this lecture originally presented on November 20
language: speaker Jennifer L. Roberts of Harvard University explores one of the fundamental operations of printmaking—reversal—in order to trace its impact on American art across a spectrum of media. Behind every print lies a matrix (from the Latin for mother): a plate or block or stone or screen from which the print has been "pulled." And in most printing processes
thumbnailurl: the final print is a reversed version of the matrix. Although reversal may seem at first to be a simple geometrical switching operation
playurl: its material and philosophical complexity is profound; indeed
downloadurl: one may posit a kind of "negative intelligence" that informs any work of art that deploys reversal. To focus on reversal is to open up new ways of thinking about connections among the fine
keywords: decorative
tags: and industrial arts in America
imageurl: not least because so many prominent American artists from the 18th through the 20th century had backgrounds in print and printmaking. "Apprenticed as an engraver"; "trained as a lithographer"; "found initial success as a commercial artist": such are the typical preludes of American artists' biographies. A rigorous analysis of reversal offers an opportunity to expand the adventure of print from the preludes into the main narratives of the stories we tell about American art. The lecture addresses reversal in several contexts
presentationdate: from the nature prints of Joseph Breintnall in the 1730s to the handprints of Jasper Johns in the 1960s
releasedate:
with a core focus on the later 19th century in the work of James McNeill Whistler and the American trompe-l'oeil painters.

"

downloadurl: bourgeois era. Thomas Eakins (1844–1916)
keywords: born and educated in Philadelphia and trained at the Ãcole des Beaux-Arts in Paris
tags: painted about two hundred fifty finished portraits in his lifetime (apart from portrait-related figure subjects)
imageurl: most of which depict the sitter at life size but on a small canvas that shows less than half the figure. But from the very outset of his career
presentationdate: and with increasing frequency after 1889
releasedate: he essayed full-length portraits in the Grand Manner. Between 1870 and 1909
lastmodified": when he all but ceased painting
column17: either seated or standing. A closer look at the choice and treatment of these relatively few sitters teaches us much about Eakins
column21: every great portrait is a picture of the artist
column22: this “grand” series reveals in the most ambitious format the identity of the artist
column23: covertly buried in the elaborate perspective coordinates of each composition
column24: or enacted in a private pantheon of colleagues—artists

and teachers—that embody his grandest aspirations and mirror his sense of self.

language: the Little Dancer is the only three-dimensional work that he chose to exhibit during his lifetime. The video provides 360 degrees of footage

and costume.

title: El Greco:  An Artist's Odyssey
duration: this film was made in conjunction with the exhibition El Greco in the National Gallery of Art and Washington-Area Collections: A 400th Anniversary Celebration. El Greco (1541 – 1614) was born Domenikos Theotokopoulos in Crete. He began his career as a painter of icons for Byzantine churches. Moving to Italy and then to Spain
language: his work fused lessons learned from the glories of Byzantium with the ravishing color of Venetian art and the elegant artificialities of Roman mannerism. Settling in Toledo
thumbnailurl: he created a passionate outpouring of work. He painted haunting portraits of saints and scholars
playurl: biblical scenes
downloadurl: martyrdoms
keywords: and miracles in a highly personal
tags: visionary style charged with emotion and drama. His work puzzled many contemporaries
imageurl: but later artists
presentationdate: including Picasso
releasedate:
considered him a prophet of modernism.
"

title: Vasari's Lives of Piero di Cosimo and the Limits of a Teleological System
description: Giorgio Vasari wrote two biographies of the Florentine painter Piero di Cosimo: the text published in the second edition of his Lives of the Most Eminent Painters
language: and Architects in 1568 is a much-revised version of the first
thumbnailurl: printed in 1550. Both works are profoundly teleological
playurl: since they are both based on a misleading notion of artistic progress: the first culminating in the figure of Michelangelo
downloadurl: who mastered all three major arts
keywords: and the second ending with the eulogy of the Accademia del Disegno
tags: recently founded (1563) under the political auspices of Duke Cosimo I de’ Medici. As Alessandro Nova shows in this lecture
imageurl: Piero’s lives do not fit the theoretical model
presentationdate: and their meaning can be fully appreciated only when they are embedded in a network that connects Vasari’s rÃ©cit of Paolo Uccello’s biography with his fictional life of Jacopo Pontormo. All three were represented as improper intellectual figures deeply absorbed in their creative process
releasedate: and their behavior allegedly endangered Vasari’s efforts to promote a new figure of the artist perfectly integrated into the courtly society of his time.​ Recorded on February 18

title: Drawing in Silver and Gold: Leonardo to Jasper Johns
description: This film was produced in conjunction with the exhibition Drawing in Silver and Gold: Leonardo to Jasper Johns. Used by artists since the Middle Ages

language: head of paper conservation at the National Gallery of Art

playurl: the Gallery’s chief of design

comments on the techniques used by the artists. This film is made possible by the HRH Foundation.

"

title: American Journeys: Visions of Place
duration: a two-time Pulitzer Prize–winning author and recipient of the National Book Award
language: discusses a selection of American paintings and sculptures in the Corcoran Gallery of Art collection
thumbnailurl: now part of the National Gallery of Art. In this interview filmed in 2013 at McCullough’s Martha’s Vineyard home
playurl:
the author of The Greater Journey: Americans in Paris provides enlightening commentary on American art and history as seen through the lens of works included in a 2013–2014 Corcoran installation titled American Journeys: Visions of Place.  Many of these works will go on view in the American and European galleries beginning in May 2015. The film is made possible by the HRH Foundation.

"

title: Gauguin: Maker of Myth
description: Narrated by Willem Dafoe and with Alfred Molina as the voice of Paul Gauguin
duration: this film was made in conjunction with the exhibition Gauguin: Maker of Myth. Gauguin (1848–1903) abandoned impressionism to create an art driven less by observation than by imagination. His gifts as an artist were matched by a talent for creating myths about places
thumbnailurl: and most of all
playurl: himself. This film explores his search for an authenticity he felt missing in modern Europe
downloadurl: a search that took him to ever more remote lands: Brittany
keywords: Martinique
tags: and Polynesia. Never finding the paradise of his dreams
imageurl: he recreated it in his paintings
presentationdate: sculpture
releasedate: drawings
lastmodified":
and prints. The film is available for sale at the National Gallery of Art. The film is made possible by the HRH Foundation.

"

title: Self-Portrait
duration: Gauguin’s unnerving Self-Portrait is painted on a dining room cupboard door from an inn in the Breton hamlet Le Pouldu in northwest France. The viewer must decide whether this disembodied head floating against a field of crimson and warm yellow represents Gauguin as Christ with a halo or is Satan holding the snake that tempted Eve to eat the forbidden apples

title: Ginevra de’ Benci
duration:
Leonardo’s subtly painted portrait of Ginevra de’ Benci was probably commissioned on the occasion of her engagement at age 16 to Luigi Niccolini. A motto painted on the reverse—VIRTUTEM FORMA DECORAT (“Beauty adorns virtue”)—suggests that the young woman’s chastity was as pristine as her flawless complexion.

"

title: Woman Holding a Balance
duration: Vermeer echoes the stillness of the instrument held lightly in the woman’s hands with a masterful balance of color
thumbnailurl:
and shade throughout the composition. The scene is rendered with acute attention to detail and naturalism but also contains an allegorical subtext. The figure’s action of balancing the scales and her placement in front of a painting depicting the Last Judgment reminds the viewer to live a temperate and virtuous life.

"

title: Self-Portrait
thumbnailurl: and etched dozens of self-portraits over his lifetime. Together
playurl: his self-portraits form an extended study of a wide range of human emotions and states of mind. This work was painted shortly after the artist had declared bankruptcy and experienced other hardships. It is tempting to discern an aura of melancholy in the serious expression
downloadurl:
but the steady gaze and expressive handling of the paint emphasizing the eyes lends a sense of dignity and strength to the sitter.

"

title: The Old Musician
duration: Manet’s tableau reflects on the isolated nature of modern life in this depiction of a group of disparate people. The artist sympathized with the displaced and marginalized poor population
language: a result of the dramatic redesigning of the Paris that created the now-familiar wide
thumbnailurl:
tree-lined boulevards and neoclassical buildings.

"

title: Self-Portrait
duration:
Van Gogh created at least 36 self-portraits. This was one of the last he completed in his decade-long career and the first he painted after suffering a severe breakdown in 1889. Van Gogh shows himself holding his painting tools. It appears that the work was completed in one sitting.

"

title: Rouen Cathedral Facades
duration: Two of Monet’s 30 renderings of the Rouen Cathedral are in the NGA collection. The artist ensured a good view of his subject by renting a second-story room in the hotel across the street from the church as a temporary studio. Throughout the day
language: he studied the effects of light and shade on the faÃ§ade and captured them on canvas. Though these look like they might have been painted quickly
thumbnailurl: conservators have discovered that the paint dried in between layers
playurl: which means that Monet worked on the canvases slowly
downloadurl:
over a long period of time.

"

title: The Feast of the Gods
duration: The only artist to surpass the Renaissance painter Bellini’s reputation in Venice was his pupil and collaborator on this painting: Titian. This lively composition
language: which shows a scene about to erupt with sound and action
thumbnailurl: was painted for Duke Alfonso d’Este and illustrates Ovid’s poem “The Feasts” (Fasti). The Duke’s guests would have delighted in identifying the classical source and untangling the identities of the dozen gods
playurl: goddesses
downloadurl:
and mythological beings.

"

title: Daniel in the Lions’ Den
duration: This painting illustrates the power of Daniel’s faith to protect him from the restless
language: roaring lions. During the Protestant Reformation
thumbnailurl:
this biblical tale about the trials of an early Christian martyr was used by the Catholic Church to represent perseverance through persecution. Rubens captures the restrained yet menacing energy of the oversized lions with their dynamic poses and lifelike appearance. The strong upward diagonal created by Daniel’s body and red garment indicate the drama of the moment of Daniel’s salvation as the rock sealing the cavernous prison is rolled away.

"

title: George Bellows
duration: this film was made in conjunction with the exhibition George Bellows. Bellows arrived in New York City in 1904 and depicted an America on the move. In a twenty-year career cut short by his death at age 42
language: he painted the rapidly growing modern city—its bustling crowds
thumbnailurl: skyscrapers
playurl: and awe-inspiring construction projects
downloadurl: as well as its bruising boxers
keywords: street urchins
tags: and New Yorkers both hard at work and enjoying their leisure. He also captured the rugged beauty of New York's rivers and the grandeur of costal Maine. This documentary includes original footage shot in New York City and Maine; examples of Bellows' paintings
imageurl: drawings
presentationdate:
and prints; and archival footage and photographs. The film is made possible by the HRH Foundation.

"

title: LaocoÃ¶n
duration: This is El Greco’s only painting of a mythological scene. LaocoÃ¶n
language: a priest in the city of Troy
thumbnailurl: warned his countrymen not to accept the gift of the Trojan horse
playurl: which concealed enemy Greek soldiers. The gods punished him by sending serpents to strangle him and his sons. El Greco set the Greek myth against his adopted Spanish city of Toledo
downloadurl:
which appears in other paintings by the artist. The highly expressive color and energetic brush strokes are also hallmarks of El Greco’s highly individual style.

"

title: Wivenhoe Park
thumbnailurl: lush green groves
playurl: and languidly grazing cows immediately evoke the calm tranquility of a pastoral landscape. Constable was born and raised in Suffolk
downloadurl: a county near Essex northeast of London
keywords: where he developed an attachment to the rural countryside. The owner of Wivenhoe Park
tags: who was also a close friend of the artist’s father
imageurl:
commissioned this painting.

"

title: The Marquesa de Pontejos
duration:
Goya shows the marchesa dressed in the height of fashion with a wasp-waisted corset and the adoption of the “shepherdess” style popularized by Marie Antoinette. Her full skirt and broad-brimmed straw hat were also influenced by foreign fashions popular within Spain. The carnation she holds and the roses tucked into her skirt suggest that this portrait was probably painted on the occasion of her first marriage.

"

title: Breezing Up (A Fair Wind)
duration: Four boys perch on the high side of a steeply heeling catboat buffeted by choppy bottle-green water. The boat’s home port
thumbnailurl: is lettered on the stern. Homer painted this scene during a postwar period during which many Americans longed for representations of a more innocent time. The painting enjoyed immediate popularity when exhibited in the country’s centennial year of 1876. Homer would turn increasingly to painting sea and seaside scenes
playurl: especially around Gloucester
downloadurl:
Massachusetts.

"

title: The Annunciation
duration: The tall narrow format of this painting suggests that this would have been the left wing of a triptych. Van Eyck emphasizes the meaning of the annunciation
language: the moment when Mary learns of the impending birth of Christ from the angel Gabriel
thumbnailurl: by including symbolic references to the Old Testament even as this story marks the start of the New Testament. For example
playurl:
the floor tiles illustrate the stories of David and Goliath as well as Samson destroying the Philistine temple. Both foreshadow events of Christ’s life and the salvation of humankind.

"

title: Shaw Memorial
duration: Saint-Gaudens’s memorial commemorates the sacrifice of Colonel Robert Gould Shaw and the men of the 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry
language: the first black regiment to fight for the North in the Civil War. Half of the 600 men in the regiment were killed
thumbnailurl: captured
playurl: or missing after their assault on Fort Wagner
downloadurl: South Carolina on July 18
keywords: 1863. News of their bravery was spread immediately by both Union and Confederate troops. Saint-Gaudens completely reimagined the traditional equestrian monument by transforming the usual man on a horse into this frieze
tags: which commemorates the soldiers as well as their leader
imageurl:
who was the first to die.

"

title: Keelmen Heaving in Coals by Moonlight
duration: Turner’s atmospheric harbor view blends the heavy
language: thick smoke coming from the fiery braziers with an evocative
thumbnailurl:
romantic seascape. The men heave coals onto the sailing ships that line the shore in a forest of prickly masts. The moon reflects on the still water so brightly that that the viewer momentarily wonders whether the scene is illuminated by the afternoon sun.

"

title: Death and the Miser
language: which might have been one portion of a triptych
thumbnailurl: illustrates the ars moriendi
playurl: or the “Art of Dying
downloadurl: ” a popular theme at this time. Death
keywords: in the form of a skeleton
tags: comes to claim a miser’s soul in his last moments. Despite the urging of an angel
imageurl: who places his hand protectively on the dying man’s shoulder
presentationdate:
he may be unable to resist the bag of gold and other worldly treasures proffered by the demons scattered throughout the room.

"

exhibition curator Sarah Greenough and Mark Ruwedel discuss the significant contribution of his photographs to the exhibition and their place within the arc of his career.

title: ""Gustave Caillebotte: The Painter’s Eye

title: Science and Paper: Conserving a Drypoint by Michael Heizer
description: The issue of preservation arises frequently in discussions of land art and monumental outdoor sculpture
duration: the type of work for which Michael Heizer is best known. For his Scrap Metal Drypoints
language: Heizer selected salvaged zinc and aluminum plates scarred with appealing scrapes
thumbnailurl: scratches
playurl: marks of oxidation
downloadurl: and corrosion—all dramatic evidence of environmental effects. In preparation for exhibition
keywords: conservators and curators
tags: in consultation with the artist
imageurl: elected to restore the clarity of one of the prints by mitigating the distracting staining and discoloration visible in the paper support. The challenge of handling and maneuvering the eight-foot-long print—particularly when swollen with water—requires seamless coordination. Over a period of three days
presentationdate: the monumental print was bathed in calcified water in a custom-built sink
releasedate: removing much of the paper’s general discoloration. Once the print was lifted from the bath and dried under blotters
lastmodified": the conservators examined the remaining stains and selectively treated them by brushing and spraying weak solutions of bleach. A final bath removed all remaining chemical solutions from the paper. After a long period of drying
column16:
the print was hinged and framed for display in the exhibit The Serial Impulse at Gemini G.E.L.

title: Hubert Robert at the Flower-Strewn Abyss
language: University of Illinois at Chicago. On the occasion of the exhibition <i>Hubert Robert
thumbnailurl: 1733–1808 at the National Gallery of Art
playurl: Nina Dubin presented a lecture on September 26
keywords: that examined a series of Hubert Robert’s paintings from the 1780s. The theme of these works is courtship menaced by the potential for calamity. Male suitors climb ladders in an attempt to procure flowers for their female love interests or cling to tree branches while trying to secure a token of their affection in the form of a bird’s nest. No less than his contemporaneous views of Paris—evocations of a city vacillating between prosperity and ruin—Robert’s chronicles of the rise and potential fall of a man in love embody the suspenseful confluence of dread and hope that characterized the prerevolutionary period. As Dubin argues
tags: it is no accident that in such a climate

title: German Expressionism and Degenerate Art

column16: at the National Gallery of Art
column17: senior lecturer David Gariff explores the nature of German expressionist art against the backdrop of two important exhibitions mounted by the Nazis in 1937: <i>The Great German Art Exhibition

title: Tintoretto: Artist of Renaissance Venice
description: Jacopo Tintoretto (1518/19 – 1594) changed the face of Venetian painting. His loose
duration: fast and furious brushwork was compared to a thunderbolt. Combining the rich colors of Titian with the dramatic muscularity of Michelangelo’s human figures
language:
Tintoretto covered the walls of his native city with pictures that astounded his contemporaries; one critic declared him “the most extraordinary brain that the art of painting has ever produced.” This documentary includes original footage of Tintoretto’s works in the churches and palaces of Venice and interviews with curators and scholars. This film was made possible by the HRH Foundation.

title: A Conversation with Richard Mosse

playurl: National Gallery of Art
downloadurl: and Andrea Nelson
keywords: associate curator of photographs
tags: National Gallery of Art Irish photographer Richard Mosse (b. 1980) attempts to capture the complex realities of loss and destruction. Having gained initial recognition and acclaim for his work on the conflict in the Democratic Republic of the Congo
imageurl: Mosse became increasingly frustrated with the constraints of conventional documentary photography. In an attempt to refresh the medium and reengage viewers
presentationdate: Mosse began using a military-grade surveillance camera
releasedate: focusing on migrants and refugee camps. Locating his subjects and creating images through thermal radiation
lastmodified": Mosse subverts the aggression of the military technology to reveal the hardships of those displaced by war. This work culminated in the 52-minute video Incoming
column16: filmed by Trevor Tweeten with a score by Ben Frost
column17: that vacillates between scenes of the profoundly beautiful and the meditative
column18: the terrifying and the horrific. In conjunction with the installation opening at the National Gallery of Art on November 17
column20: Mosse discusses this narrative of displacement and migration in a conversation with curators Sarah Greenough and Andrea Nelson. Incoming is on view through March 22
